taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Latin picis, pitch, name of a pitchy pine]

statement.text: Bark gray to reddish-brown, thin and scaly (with thin plates), sometimes with resin blisters (especially in Picea engelmannii and P. glauca), becoming relatively thick and furrowed with age.
Buds ovoid, apex rounded to acute, sometimes resinous.
Leaves borne singly, spreading in all directions from twigs, persisting to 10 years, mostly 4-angled and square in cross-section (to triangular or ± flattened), mostly rigid, sessile on peglike base;
base decurrent, persistent after leaves shed, sheath absent;
apex usually sharp-pointed, sometimes bluntly acute;
Pollen cones grouped, axillary, oblong, yellow to purple.

Seed-cones maturing in 1 season, usually shed at maturity (persisting for several years in Picea mariana), borne mostly on upper branches, pendent, ovoid to cylindric, sessile or terminal on leafy branchlets and thus appearing ± stalked;
scales persistent, elliptic to fan-shaped, thin, lacking apophysis and umbo;
north temperate regions, North America, Mexico, Eurasia.

bio:treatment.discussion: Species ca. 35 (8 in the flora with 7 native and 1 naturalized):

references.reference: Roche, L. 1969. A genecological study of the genus Picea and seedlings grown in a nursery. New Phytol. 68: 505--554.
Taylor, R.J. and T.F. Patterson. 1980. Biosystematics of Mexican spruce species and populations. Taxon 29: 421--469.
Wright, J.W. 1955. Species crossability in spruce in relation to distribution and taxonomy. Forest Sci. 1: 319--349.

statement.text: Leaves flattened or broadly triangular in cross-section;
stomates occurring only on, or more conspicuously on, adaxial leaf surface;
stomates occurring more or less equally on all leaf surfaces;
seed-cone scales elliptic to narrowly diamond-shaped.
Leaf apex blunt, especially on older leaves;
cone-scales usually fan-shaped, broadest near apex;
cone-scales usually ± diamond-shaped or elliptic, broadest near middle (broadest at apex in Picea glauca);
leaves 0.6-1.5 (-2) cm, mostly blunt-tipped, glaucous, blue to gray-green.
leaves 0.8-2.5 (-3) cm, mostly acute, sharp-pointed, not glaucous, yellow-green to dark green.
Seed-cone scales fan-shaped, margin at apex q entire, apex extending 0.5-3 mm beyond seed-wing impression;
Seed-cone scales diamond-shaped or elliptic, margin at apex irregularly toothed to erose, apex usually extending 3 mm or more beyond seed-wing impression;
cone-scales extending 3-8 mm beyond seed-wing impression;
cone-scales extending 8-10 mm beyond seed-wing impression;
Leaves sharp-pointed or less often bluntly acute, somewhat flattened or more or less square in cross-section, sessile;
Twigs conspicuously roughened by decurrent, spreading or appressed, peglike projections that persist after leaves fall.
scales of seed-cones lacking apophyses and umbos;
mature trees of various habit, often conic, often more than 15 m;
habitat various, but mostly not of arid areas in w North America.
Leaves borne singly along branches, not scaly-sheathed at base or, if so when young, then terete.
cone-scales extending 3-8 mm beyond seed-wing impression;
Seed-cone scales diamond-shaped or elliptic, margin at apex irregularly toothed to erose, apex usually extending 3 mm or more beyond seed-wing impression;
cone-scales usually ± diamond-shaped or elliptic, broadest near middle (broadest at apex in Picea glauca);
stomates occurring more or less equally on all leaf surfaces;
